thirdch.description: Jun Wang catalogues the various enumerations of the Harvard Depository.
thirdch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https:www.youtube.com/embed/YcWBAGaALmM?rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: The music used here to show the open corridors and decorative statues was slowed and modified to underscore the functional fans and sealed corridors of the Depository.
thirdch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https:www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=221&end=236rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: "The Harvard Depository was first conceived in the mid-1980s as an economical solution to the needs of many Harvard libraries. It is more than an efficient warehouse. It is a true innovation—a new kind of library service center driven by the needs of librarians for more space and a better preservation environment and the concerns of administrators to control costs. As you are about to see, the Depository’s innovative construction and unique mode of operation enable it to do 4 things very well: provide a high level of physical control over materials, establish an ideal climate for paper-based materials and certain non-print media, ensure the rapid retrieval of materials on demand, and control costs associated with traditional library operations."
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=56&end=105rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: "Each unit is 36 feet high by 45 feet wide by 192 feet long with over 9,000 square feet of shelving space.” A lot has changed since 1993—the Depository now has over 127,000 square feet of storage.
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=139&end=149rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: “Special book tray guides have been developed to protect books from possible damage from the shelving bracing. An innovative integral clip mechanism has been created, which combines the functions of shelf brackets and tray guides.”
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=170&end=184rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: “The stack area is windowless and to protect materials from exposure to light, the stacks are illuminated by sodium vapor lamps to about 5 foot-candles.”
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=566&end=576rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Turning order picker.
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=420&end=426rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Turning order picker.
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=613&end=620rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Rising order picker from the perspective of the cab.
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=411&end=414rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Laser scanning in the aisles.  “Using portable scanners, shelvers record the location and tray number for each tray shelved. This step associates the tray barcode with the unique shelf or location barcode. When all trays are shelved, this information is downloaded from the portable scanners into the computer system. As part of quality control, all tray-to-shelf work is checked by someone other than the original shelver.”
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=269&end=315rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Carolyn C. Morrow, Malloy-Rabinowitz Preservation Librarian, outlines the Harvard Depository's preservation advantages.
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=467&end=511rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: “The Harvard Depository was designed to provide an optimum preservation environment for the collections. Research has shown that heat, humidity, air pollution, and exposure to ultraviolet light accelerate the deterioration of library materials. The Harvard Depository was designed to minimize these agents of deterioration—protecting materials and prolonging their useful life. Unlike a conventional library building, the design of the Depository eliminates many of the problems associated with controlling the environment. The building materials were chosen for their chemical stability to avoid any interaction with stored materials. The building envelope is heavily insulated and a continuous vapor barrier prevents the migration of humidity when the weather changes rapidly."
thirdch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=517&end=565rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

thirdch.description: Receiving-tomb n. (1) A buidling or other structure in which the bodies of the dead may be placed temporarily when it is impossible or inconvenient to inter them in the usual manner. (2) Harvard President Charles William Eliot's analogy for the kind of facility to meet the library system's offsite storage needs as stated in 1902.
thirdch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.flickr.com/photos/116285016@N05/16413768755/in/set-72157649860559579/player/" width="492" height="492" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe>
